title: Shigeo Nakajima
text:
is a retired <a href="Japan">Japan</a>ese <a href="Boxing">boxer</a> who is a former <a href="World%20Boxing%20Council">WBC</a> <a href="Light%20flyweight">junior flyweight</a> champion. He is an alumnus of the <a href="Komazawa%20University">Komazawa University</a>.
Nakajima began boxing at Yonekura Boxing Gym at the age of a high school student. He compiled an amateur record of 80–15 (48 KOs) before turning professional.
Nakajima made his professional debut with a second-round knockout victory at the <a href="Korakuen%20Hall">Korakuen Hall</a> in <a href="Tokyo">Tokyo</a> in July 1976, and won over the reigning Japanese junior flyweight champion Kazunori Tenryū via a third-round knockout in a non-title ten round bout in August 1977. However, he was knocked out by the former <a href="World%20Boxing%20Association">WBA</a> <a href="flyweight">flyweight</a> champion <a href="Bernabe%20Villacampo">Bernabe Villacampo</a> with a body blow in the fourth round in March 1978. He lost on points to the future WBA junior flyweight champion Hwan-Jin Kim in August of that year.
On January 3, 1980, Nakajima fought against <a href="Kim%20Sung-Jun">Kim Sung-Jun</a> for the WBC junior flyweight title at the Korakuen Hall. Preparing for that fight, Joe Koizumi who is familiar with the boxing theory and was later inducted into the <a href="International%20Boxing%20Hall%20of%20Fame">International Boxing Hall of Fame</a> and the <a href="World%20Boxing%20Hall%20of%20Fame">World Boxing Hall of Fame</a>, served as Nakajima's trainer. The gym's president <a href="Kenji%20Yonekura">Kenji Yonekura</a> made him move to an apartment near his residence, and woke him up every morning to make him do his roadwork. In the third round, his <a href="eardrum">eardrum</a> was perforated and his <a href="rib">rib</a>s cracked, and he suffered a cut above his left eye. Nevertheless, Nakajima was crowned the title via a unanimous decision with his quick blows and footwork.
In his first defense in March 1980, he lost to <a href="Hilario%20Zapata">Hilario Zapata</a> via a close unanimous decision at the <a href="Kuramae%20Kokugikan">Kuramae Kokugikan</a> in Tokyo. Yonekura protested that decision of the judges. Yet Nakajima was stopped in the eleventh round of the rematch with Zapata for that title at the Civic Center in <a href="Gifu%2C%20Gifu">Gifu city</a> in September of the same year. After eight months, Nakajima suffered an eight-round knockout loss, and quit boxing.
Nakajima once serves as the president of the golf course development company, and currently acts as the executive secretary of the Pro Boxing World Champions party which is the internal organization of the Japan Pro Boxing Association (JPBA) consisting of Japan's world champions for the social contributions.
